summary: You know i heard the forbidden fruit actually was a pear
question: You know i heard the forbidden fruit actually was a pear
answer: Aziraphale: You’re going to put me off pears, and that would be a dratting shame!

blog.name: luciferwritings
blog.title: and miles to go before i sleep
blog.description: he/him | 21 | my main blog is @disasterfag | i’m very pretentious

body:
ineffable.

1.

Since the dawning of time

I have looked in your eyes

and seen there a glimmer

of something unsaid

Something so different

Something so real

I know it is there

and it can’t be for me.

My family shunned me,

for choices I made

They cast me aside,

told me I’d dug my grave

Unforgivable, serpent,

wretched is my name.

But how am I wretched

for asking what’s right?

How am I fallen

for sins so slight?

I may have spread doubt,

but there’s one thing I know;

I’ve loved you for ever

like the moon loves the snow

You may never know

and you may never care;

Angel, I love you,

but how could I tell?

You’d never stoop as low

as to love someone like me.

2.

We’ve stood side by side

through history’s first storm

Centuries tenfold and sixfold again

We meet, by chance, by luck, by love.

Of course I love you, darling,

for Love is what I am

- though not the love I have for you,

that love must stay inside.

I need them to love me,

I need them to care

I’d go with you without a doubt

if only they weren’t there.

I know it is pathetic,

to need what they won’t give

I tell myself, just try some more,

and you’ll be on dry ground

But I know it all will burst one day,

I know they will find out

And then I’ll be here, all alone

a nightmare come to life.

I love you more than anything,

I love you more than life

but how could I tell you?

Why would you care?

You’d never stoop so low

as to love someone like me.

blog.name: blkholeinfinity
blog.title: just your everyday lurker
blog.description:
32 | biro ace | she/her | asian-american
fandoms: Good Omens, Jane the Virgin, MCU, Brooklyn 99, A:TLA and Legend of Korra, a bunch of other random things tbh
There is little rhyme or reason to what I blog about, sorry. :(

summary: Asian Rep in Good Omens; or, I love Pollution (the character) and the fact that they’re played by an Asian actress
title: Asian Rep in Good Omens; or, I love Pollution (the character) and the fact that they’re played by an Asian actress
body:
Asians in media are still so rare, and the media is getting better at representing us, but man, as an Asian-American, I am always starved for what I can get.

So while the Good Omens miniseries only had one main Asian actor, with the other Asians being extras/very minor roles, I have to say, I LOVE Lourdes Faberes as Pollution. In my experience, if an Asian was cast in something like Good Omens, they’d be cast as Wensleydale at best, Madame Tracy at worst. Wensleydale would have played into the “smart, nerdy Asian child destined to become something Smart (in this case an accountant (at least not a lawyer/doctor/engineer?))” which you see in so many children’s movies from the 80′s and 90′s. Madame Tracy, on the other hand, would have played into the exotic “Oriental” prostitute stereotype, which, ugh. 

Don’t get me wrong, I love and adore both of these characters, but casting Asians in these roles would have been problematic, and I’m so glad that’s not what happened here.

Pollution, on the other hand? Brilliant.

First of all, Pollution is outside of the typecast Asian actors normally find themselves in when we do get to be in a movie or TV show. They aren’t a nerdy sidekick, they aren’t a skilled martial artist, and thank god they aren’t a ~exotic~ ~sexy~ seducer type. (Lourdes Faberes is sexy, but that wasn’t the point, is what I’m getting at.) Yes, Pollution is a villain type, but a neutral villain type, and a compelling one at that.

Second, Pollution is non-binary. I am not in a position to talk about non-binary rep, but if seeing Asians in media is rare, seeing Asian LGBT+ rep is even rarer, so I truly appreciated this. Beyond that, I can only be an audience to any non-binary discourse.

Third, and this is getting into some meta, I love how appropriate Pollution being Asian is. Some of the worst polluted countries in the world are Asian countries. I don’t know if this was intentional or not (tbh, I think it was just a lucky coincidence), but it just makes sense. And no, I don’t see this as racist: reminder that I am Asian, and I grew up in Asia. I am proud to be Asian, but part of pride is acknowledging faults, and there are definitely Asian countries who are just bad about pollution, and objectively worse than other countries (even if the U.S. is trying to give them a run for their money, ugh). So having an Asian actress play Pollution just works, for my money.

Could there have been more Asians in the cast outside of basically the extras/very minor roles? Sure, but at the same time, I don’t feel like Pollution was token representation. And honestly, I think the only character who I feel would have been brilliantly served as Asian is Newt if only for a major trope subversion: an Asian who is terrible with computers, ya’ll. But I adore Jack Whitehall and the rest of the cast, so that’s as far as I’m going to go there.

And am I bothered that an Asian is playing a non-human role? Absolutely not. Asians should be allowed and given the opportunity to play all manners of roles, including non-human roles. Am I bothered that the one Asian main character is non-human? Nope. Because Asians should be allowed and given the opportunity to play all manners of roles. 

tl;dr - an Asian playing Pollution is not problematic representation, it’s brilliant, and this Asian is not even the slightest bit offended and is, in fact, thrilled that Lourdes Faberes had this opportunity.

Don’t get me wrong, I love and adore both of these characters, but casting Asians in these roles would have been problematic, and I’m so glad that’s not what happened here.

blog.name: eros-heartache
blog.title: Eros Heartache
blog.description: 100% NOT here for anyone to validate me, Multifandom shitposter, Hedonist/Libertine, random other shit.... Message from Me: You own your shit, you walk your talk. Its fantastic to be loved and happy, but own the knowlege you can and will be a problematic person to someone. You can be hated with validity and with take ownership of your faults. In the end you will never make yourself anything more than the sum of your life, perceptions and expierance. And that wisdom my loves, Is what makes all the diffence.

summary:
Person facing a hard decision: Hmm...
Angel and Devil: *appears on their shoulders*
Angel: Do you really think you...
body:
Person facing a hard decision: Hmm...
Angel and Devil: *appears on their shoulders*
Angel: Do you really think you should?
Crowley: What? Oh, hang on. *Gets up from where he was lounging beside Aziraphale and goes onto the other shoulder.* Yea, do it. Or don't; I wasn't really listening.

dialogue.name: Angel
dialogue.label: Angel:
dialogue.phrase: Do you really think you should?

dialogue.name: Crowley
dialogue.label: Crowley:
dialogue.phrase: What? Oh, hang on. *Gets up from where he was lounging beside Aziraphale and goes onto the other shoulder.* Yea, do it. Or don't; I wasn't really listening.

body:
@purpleemeraldot replied to your post “You can’t blame Crowley for taking up Aziraphale’s offer. The first…”

This is so cuuuute! And yes I do agree with crowley on this… OYSTERS ARE GOOOOOOOO

When I saw the notif for this, I just assumed the end of “GOOOOOOOOD” had been cut off and then remembered I had actually written Crowley calling oysters goo…

tags: i just really hate strawberry and banana flavours
love strawberries and bananas hate the flavours and also hate strawberry banana flavour
but lemon and cherry and also lemon cherry were gifts from above
summary: Clearly, heaven came up with lemon and Crowley, for hell, responsed with "let's ruin this gift from god by making another yellow...
body:
Clearly, heaven came up with lemon and Crowley, for hell, responsed with “let’s ruin this gift from god by making another yellow flavour that literally embodies disappointment and disgust. What flavor? Banana, of course. That way humans have to play Russian roulette with any yellow candy”

The same later happened when heaven made cherry flavoring. All of the sudden, strawberry existed too. Yes I know Aziraphale ordered a strawberry popsicle but he could have been keeping up appearances or supporting his husband’s creations don’t @ me

[COMMISSIONS ARE ON HIATUS] 
--> http://0-aredhel-0.tumblr.com/post/122257624926/open-commisions-you-can-contact-me-via-tumblr

Spanish girl, 28.

DC, Batman, Robin. Dick, as in penis and as in Richard. MARVEL. Avengers. X-MEN. Captain America. Blacksad. 

Tolkien. Harry Potter. Les Misérables. A Song of Ice and Fire. The Outsiders. The Hunger Games. The Princess Bride. The Name of the Wind. The Raven Cycle. Skulduggery Pleasant.

Star Wars. Disney. Ghibli. The Fall. Tim Burton. Pacific Rim. Star Trek. LAIKA. 

Avatar. Steven Universe. Voltron: Legendary Defender. Gravity Falls. Phineas&Ferb. Haikyuu!! DCMK. Digimon. Neon Génesis Evangelion. Over the Garden Wall. Drawn Together. FMA.

Parks & Recreation. Penny Dreadful. Criminal Minds. Firefly. Once Upon a Time. Scrubs. Buffy the Vampire Slayer. Misfits. House MD. FRIENDS. Pushing Daisies. Supernatural. Sherlock. Teen Wolf. Hannibal. Community. Orange is the new black. Brooklyn 99. Wynonna Earp. Sense8. A Series of Unfortunate Events. The Umbrella Academy.

Kingdom Hearts. Final Fantasy VIII. Ace Attorney. Prof. Layton.

GOT7. VIXX. Seventeen. Monsta X.

Hamilton.

Ask me anything! I love talking to you guys C:

tags: i warned you about a hirando good omens au bro!! i warned you!
anyway i dont know if im going to continue this at all. probably not tbh. but i might!
hey did you know that i write stuff sometimes?
summary: It was a relatively calm day in terms of traffic, which was a rarity to end all rarities at that time in the evening. This...
body:
It was a relatively calm day in terms of traffic, which was a rarity to end all rarities at that time in the evening. This stopped being true very quickly as a blue Nissan Versa rounded a corner and barrelled down the road toward a comic book store. The screech of the vehicle’s tires were nearly–although not quite–loud enough to drown out the Queen music it was blasting. As the Versa reached the comic book store, it pulled to a halt and a man in sunglasses stepped out.

As he walked in, the little bell on the door chimed, catching the attention of the shop’s proprietor, who was currently lounging in a beanbag chair. He had been there for several hours now, or perhaps several days, depending on how long it took for dust to start gathering on someone.

“We’re closed!” Hiro called out without looking up from his first-edition original-run Superman comic. “Go away!”

“It’s me, Hiro-kun.”

“Oh!” Lowering the comic, Hiro glanced up to see Ando leaning in the doorway, hand in his pocket. “Ando-kun. What brings you here?”

Ando grimaced as he walked over to sit down beside Hiro*. As he turned to face him, Ando took off his sunglasses and tucked them in his jacket pocket, showing off his snake eyes. Hiro looked at him expectantly. As much as he may have secretly wished otherwise, Ando didn’t usually drop by without a reason. He wondered if he was going to invite him out to dinner again, or perhaps he just wanted to get drunk and unwind in Hiro’s backroom.

[* he pulled up a chair that certainly hadn’t been next to the beanbag chair before, and most likely would no longer be there after he stood back up.]

“Well…” Ando hesitated for a moment, then let out a beleaguered sigh. “Armageddon is officially on.”

Hiro blinked in surprise.

“It can’t be time for that yet!” he objected. “Can’t your side wait a little longer?”

Ando shrugged as if to say, “why not check the future for yourself if you don’t believe me?”

“Well, can’t you tell them to put it off?” Hiro persisted. “I don’t want the world to end yet! What about all my comics? And–well, all the people and cities and everything,” he added quickly. “Especially America. I must say, I’ve gotten rather attached to America.”

“Oh, believe me, I know,” said Ando. “It almost makes me think… hmm.” He hummed in contemplation, brow furrowing slightly.

“What?” Hiro prompted.

“Ehh, it’s nothing,” Ando said, waving his hand dismissively. “Nothing that’d ever work, anyway.”

At this, Hiro perked up. In his experience, there were a lot of things Ando thought wouldn’t work that worked out just fine. Adjusting his glasses*, he leaned forward attentively to hear his counterpart’s idea.

[* naturally, ethereal beings don’t require any sort of eyewear, but Hiro opted to wear glasses because they matched his general disposition. At least, that was what he told the higher-ups. Truth be told, he kind of hoped his next corporation would have better eyesight.]

“Well…” Ando said, “I suppose we could always try to save it.”

“Save it?” Hiro echoed. “The world?” His mouth quirked into a frown. “I’d love to, but… do you think Upstairs would allow it? They’re very strict about following the course of destiny, you know.”

“That’s true,” Ando acknowledged. He leaned back in his chair, a wine bottle manifesting in his hand. “Your side’s uptight like that. No sinning, no questioning, no straying from the path of destiny…” He paused to take a sip of wine and shot Hiro a meaningful look. “…No comics, as you say. No waffles, either.”

Right about then, a wine bottle appeared in Hiro’s hand as well. He took a sip and reflected on what Ando was saying. Truth be told, saving the world did seem like a very exciting prospect. The superheros in his comics did it all the time, and they rarely saw any serious consequences for it. Still, if the world was supposed to end, then stopping it would be going against destiny.

“How do you know the world is ending, anyway?” Hiro asked. “Did you read it in a book of prophecy? Because those things are rarely accurate, you know. Except for the Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Isaac Mendez, of course, but there aren’t any copies of that left.”

“Nope. No books of prophecy,” Ando told him. “I know… because I just got back from delivering the antichrist.”

Hiro’s eyebrows rocketed up. “Really?’

"Yep. We gave her to the family of an American diplomat*. She’s a very cute baby, really, apart from the fact that she’s the spawn of satan.”

[* as far as Ando knew, the baby swap had gone perfectly. A blonde-haired baby girl, whose new parents had named her Jackie, had indeed been delivered to the American diplomat. The other blonde-haired baby girl one room over, whose parents had named her Claire, was without a doubt a perfectly normal child and not the misplaced antichrist. Ando may or may not have been very wrong about this.]

“Well, if the antichrist is on earth, I don’t see what we can do,” Hiro said, his shoulders sagging. “I don’t really want to kill her… I suppose we could just lock her away somewhere.”

“Who said anything about killing?” Ando asked incredulously. “I just thought maybe we could provide some outside influence to her. Prevent her from growing up evil, you know?”

“Ohh! That might work,” Hiro said. For a moment he perked back up, only to immediately slump back down again when he remembered his side’s non-interference policy. “But Upstairs still isn’t going to like it. We aren’t supposed to get in the way of destiny, you know.”

“How do you know what our destiny is if the only accurate prophecy book has been destroyed?” Ando countered. “Hey, maybe it’s our destiny to interfere and protect the earth. It’s about as likely as anything, right?”

Hiro stopped to think that over and to take a sip of wine. Outside the shop, cars drove by on the street as the sun sank lower in the sky. A bird cawed somewhere off in the distance. It was a nice city, and a nice planet, for that matter. Sure, there were other planets, but Hiro did like earth. He certainly didn’t want it to be destroyed. And, well, if what Ando said was right…

“We’ll do it, then,” he decided, breaking into a grin. “Steer the antichrist onto the right path. Save the world!”

“Or try to, anyway,” Ando amended.

Grinning, Hiro snapped his fingers. Somewhere many miles away, a diner in Texas suddenly had a table reserved for two.

“On that note, would you care for breakfast?”

“Angel, it’s 5:30 PM.”

“Not in America, it isn’t,” Hiro said. Laying his hand atop Ando’s, he added, “Besides, I still owe you from… what was it, the Edo period?”

At that, Ando smiled. He laced his fingers through Hiro’s–a typically wily demonic gesture–and lowered his sunglasses back over his eyes. Hiro snapped his fingers again, and the next moment, they were comfortably seated across from each other at the Burnt Toast Diner.

Throughout their meal, they built upon their plan until they were fairly confident in it. They were going to go undercover as a nanny and a gardener*, and they would each try to sway the antichrist toward their respective side. It was hard to tell how well it would work out, but Hiro, for one, was pretty optimistic.

[* Hiro called dibs on the position of gardener, not because he was particularly fond of gardens, but because he had no interest whatsoever in looking after babies, satanic or otherwise.]

In fact, as the night went on, Hiro became quite certain that the plan would work. Having it not work would mean armageddon, after all, and that was the last thing anybody wanted. How hard could it be, really? It all boiled down to simple cause and effect: raise the antichrist, save the world.

“It’s me, Hiro-kun.”

“Oh!” Lowering the comic, Hiro glanced up to see Ando leaning in the doorway, hand in his pocket. “Ando-kun. What brings you here?”

Ando grimaced as he walked over to sit down beside Hiro*. As he turned to face him, Ando took off his sunglasses and tucked them in his jacket pocket, showing off his snake eyes. Hiro looked at him expectantly. As much as he may have secretly wished otherwise, Ando didn’t usually drop by without a reason. He wondered if he was going to invite him out to dinner again, or perhaps he just wanted to get drunk and unwind in Hiro’s backroom.

[* he pulled up a chair that certainly hadn’t been next to the beanbag chair before, and most likely would no longer be there after he stood back up.]

“Well…” Ando hesitated for a moment, then let out a beleaguered sigh. “Armageddon is officially on.”

Hiro blinked in surprise.

“It can’t be time for that yet!” he objected. “Can’t your side wait a little longer?”

Ando shrugged as if to say, “why not check the future for yourself if you don’t believe me?”

“Well, can’t you tell them to put it off?” Hiro persisted. “I don’t want the world to end yet! What about all my comics? And–well, all the people and cities and everything,” he added quickly. “Especially America. I must say, I’ve gotten rather attached to America.”

“Oh, believe me, I know,” said Ando. “It almost makes me think… hmm.” He hummed in contemplation, brow furrowing slightly.

“What?” Hiro prompted.

“Ehh, it’s nothing,” Ando said, waving his hand dismissively. “Nothing that’d ever work, anyway.”

At this, Hiro perked up. In his experience, there were a lot of things Ando thought wouldn’t work that worked out just fine. Adjusting his glasses*, he leaned forward attentively to hear his counterpart’s idea.

[* naturally, ethereal beings don’t require any sort of eyewear, but Hiro opted to wear glasses because they matched his general disposition. At least, that was what he told the higher-ups. Truth be told, he kind of hoped his next corporation would have better eyesight.]

“Well…” Ando said, “I suppose we could always try to save it.”

“Save it?” Hiro echoed. “The world?” His mouth quirked into a frown. “I’d love to, but… do you think Upstairs would allow it? They’re very strict about following the course of destiny, you know.”

“That’s true,” Ando acknowledged. He leaned back in his chair, a wine bottle manifesting in his hand. “Your side’s uptight like that. No sinning, no questioning, no straying from the path of destiny…” He paused to take a sip of wine and shot Hiro a meaningful look. “…No comics, as you say. No waffles, either.”

Right about then, a wine bottle appeared in Hiro’s hand as well. He took a sip and reflected on what Ando was saying. Truth be told, saving the world did seem like a very exciting prospect. The superheros in his comics did it all the time, and they rarely saw any serious consequences for it. Still, if the world was supposed to end, then stopping it would be going against destiny.

“How do you know the world is ending, anyway?” Hiro asked. “Did you read it in a book of prophecy? Because those things are rarely accurate, you know. Except for the Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Isaac Mendez, of course, but there aren’t any copies of that left.”

“Nope. No books of prophecy,” Ando told him. “I know… because I just got back from delivering the antichrist.”

Hiro’s eyebrows rocketed up. “Really?’

"Yep. We gave her to the family of an American diplomat*. She’s a very cute baby, really, apart from the fact that she’s the spawn of satan.”

[* as far as Ando knew, the baby swap had gone perfectly. A blonde-haired baby girl, whose new parents had named her Jackie, had indeed been delivered to the American diplomat. The other blonde-haired baby girl one room over, whose parents had named her Claire, was without a doubt a perfectly normal child and not the misplaced antichrist. Ando may or may not have been very wrong about this.]

“Well, if the antichrist is on earth, I don’t see what we can do,” Hiro said, his shoulders sagging. “I don’t really want to kill her… I suppose we could just lock her away somewhere.”

“Who said anything about killing?” Ando asked incredulously. “I just thought maybe we could provide some outside influence to her. Prevent her from growing up evil, you know?”

“Ohh! That might work,” Hiro said. For a moment he perked back up, only to immediately slump back down again when he remembered his side’s non-interference policy. “But Upstairs still isn’t going to like it. We aren’t supposed to get in the way of destiny, you know.”

“How do you know what our destiny is if the only accurate prophecy book has been destroyed?” Ando countered. “Hey, maybe it’s our destiny to interfere and protect the earth. It’s about as likely as anything, right?”

Hiro stopped to think that over and to take a sip of wine. Outside the shop, cars drove by on the street as the sun sank lower in the sky. A bird cawed somewhere off in the distance. It was a nice city, and a nice planet, for that matter. Sure, there were other planets, but Hiro did like earth. He certainly didn’t want it to be destroyed. And, well, if what Ando said was right…

“We’ll do it, then,” he decided, breaking into a grin. “Steer the antichrist onto the right path. Save the world!”

“Or try to, anyway,” Ando amended.

Grinning, Hiro snapped his fingers. Somewhere many miles away, a diner in Texas suddenly had a table reserved for two.

“On that note, would you care for breakfast?”

“Angel, it’s 5:30 PM.”

“Not in America, it isn’t,” Hiro said. Laying his hand atop Ando’s, he added, “Besides, I still owe you from… what was it, the Edo period?”

At that, Ando smiled. He laced his fingers through Hiro’s–a typically wily demonic gesture–and lowered his sunglasses back over his eyes. Hiro snapped his fingers again, and the next moment, they were comfortably seated across from each other at the Burnt Toast Diner.

Throughout their meal, they built upon their plan until they were fairly confident in it. They were going to go undercover as a nanny and a gardener*, and they would each try to sway the antichrist toward their respective side. It was hard to tell how well it would work out, but Hiro, for one, was pretty optimistic.

[* Hiro called dibs on the position of gardener, not because he was particularly fond of gardens, but because he had no interest whatsoever in looking after babies, satanic or otherwise.]

In fact, as the night went on, Hiro became quite certain that the plan would work. Having it not work would mean armageddon, after all, and that was the last thing anybody wanted. How hard could it be, really? It all boiled down to simple cause and effect: raise the antichrist, save the world.
trail.content:
It was a relatively calm day in terms of traffic, which was a rarity to end all rarities at that time in the evening. This stopped being true very quickly as a blue Nissan Versa rounded a corner and barrelled down the road toward a comic book store. The screech of the vehicle’s tires were nearly–although not quite–loud enough to drown out the Queen music it was blasting. As the Versa reached the comic book store, it pulled to a halt and a man in sunglasses stepped out.

As he walked in, the little bell on the door chimed, catching the attention of the shop’s proprietor, who was currently lounging in a beanbag chair. He had been there for several hours now, or perhaps several days, depending on how long it took for dust to start gathering on someone.

“We’re closed!” Hiro called out without looking up from his first-edition original-run Superman comic. “Go away!”

“It’s me, Hiro-kun.”

“Oh!” Lowering the comic, Hiro glanced up to see Ando leaning in the doorway, hand in his pocket. “Ando-kun. What brings you here?”

Ando grimaced as he walked over to sit down beside Hiro*. As he turned to face him, Ando took off his sunglasses and tucked them in his jacket pocket, showing off his snake eyes. Hiro looked at him expectantly. As much as he may have secretly wished otherwise, Ando didn’t usually drop by without a reason. He wondered if he was going to invite him out to dinner again, or perhaps he just wanted to get drunk and unwind in Hiro’s backroom.

[* he pulled up a chair that certainly hadn’t been next to the beanbag chair before, and most likely would no longer be there after he stood back up.]

“It can’t be time for that yet!” he objected. “Can’t your side wait a little longer?”

Ando shrugged as if to say, “why not check the future for yourself if you don’t believe me?”

“Well, can’t you tell them to put it off?” Hiro persisted. “I don’t want the world to end yet! What about all my comics? And–well, all the people and cities and everything,” he added quickly. “Especially America. I must say, I’ve gotten rather attached to America.”

“Oh, believe me, I know,” said Ando. “It almost makes me think… hmm.” He hummed in contemplation, brow furrowing slightly.

“What?” Hiro prompted.

“Ehh, it’s nothing,” Ando said, waving his hand dismissively. “Nothing that’d ever work, anyway.”

At this, Hiro perked up. In his experience, there were a lot of things Ando thought wouldn’t work that worked out just fine. Adjusting his glasses*, he leaned forward attentively to hear his counterpart’s idea.

[* naturally, ethereal beings don’t require any sort of eyewear, but Hiro opted to wear glasses because they matched his general disposition. At least, that was what he told the higher-ups. Truth be told, he kind of hoped his next corporation would have better eyesight.]

“Well…” Ando said, “I suppose we could always try to save it.”

“Save it?” Hiro echoed. “The world?” His mouth quirked into a frown. “I’d love to, but… do you think Upstairs would allow it? They’re very strict about following the course of destiny, you know.”

“That’s true,” Ando acknowledged. He leaned back in his chair, a wine bottle manifesting in his hand. “Your side’s uptight like that. No sinning, no questioning, no straying from the path of destiny…” He paused to take a sip of wine and shot Hiro a meaningful look. “…No comics, as you say. No waffles, either.”

Right about then, a wine bottle appeared in Hiro’s hand as well. He took a sip and reflected on what Ando was saying. Truth be told, saving the world did seem like a very exciting prospect. The superheros in his comics did it all the time, and they rarely saw any serious consequences for it. Still, if the world was supposed to end, then stopping it would be going against destiny.

“How do you know the world is ending, anyway?” Hiro asked. “Did you read it in a book of prophecy? Because those things are rarely accurate, you know. Except for the Nice and Accurate Prophecies of Isaac Mendez, of course, but there aren’t any copies of that left.”

“Nope. No books of prophecy,” Ando told him. “I know… because I just got back from delivering the antichrist.”

Hiro’s eyebrows rocketed up. “Really?’

"Yep. We gave her to the family of an American diplomat*. She’s a very cute baby, really, apart from the fact that she’s the spawn of satan.”

[* as far as Ando knew, the baby swap had gone perfectly. A blonde-haired baby girl, whose new parents had named her Jackie, had indeed been delivered to the American diplomat. The other blonde-haired baby girl one room over, whose parents had named her Claire, was without a doubt a perfectly normal child and not the misplaced antichrist. Ando may or may not have been very wrong about this.]

“Well, if the antichrist is on earth, I don’t see what we can do,” Hiro said, his shoulders sagging. “I don’t really want to kill her… I suppose we could just lock her away somewhere.”

Hiro stopped to think that over and to take a sip of wine. Outside the shop, cars drove by on the street as the sun sank lower in the sky. A bird cawed somewhere off in the distance. It was a nice city, and a nice planet, for that matter. Sure, there were other planets, but Hiro did like earth. He certainly didn’t want it to be destroyed. And, well, if what Ando said was right…

“Or try to, anyway,” Ando amended.

“Angel, it’s 5:30 PM.”

At that, Ando smiled. He laced his fingers through Hiro’s–a typically wily demonic gesture–and lowered his sunglasses back over his eyes. Hiro snapped his fingers again, and the next moment, they were comfortably seated across from each other at the Burnt Toast Diner.

In fact, as the night went on, Hiro became quite certain that the plan would work. Having it not work would mean armageddon, after all, and that was the last thing anybody wanted. How hard could it be, really? It all boiled down to simple cause and effect: raise the antichrist, save the world.

blog.name: reaping-royalty
blog.title: Oof
blog.description: this is my personal blog, do not have a clue what I am doing here though! reblogging stuff, I suppose? I have a [slightly] more serious fan account, reaping-royalty-writes, it's primarily Good Omens stuff, and I hardly ever write but! You should stop by anyway uwu 😊

tags: i am in absolute love with this show
summary: That bit in episode six of good omens where they make the switch and Crowley (as Aziraphale) goes to step into the flames, he...
body: That bit in episode six of good omens where they make the switch and Crowley (as Aziraphale) goes to step into the flames, he gives them this big happy-go-lucky labradpr smile and a sweet little “I don’t suppose there’s anything I could do to change your mind?” and like??????? I absolutely died right there, because it was Crowley emulating the face that Azira makes that would have Crowley jumping to do his bidding (cause Zira has him wrapped around his finger, ofc), the face that ultimately caused him to fall in love and I just cri everytime
